normalised: Hey everyone, let's talk about something really crucial: Air Quality! Especially relevant for us in India. Ever wonder why Delhi's air sometimes looks like a pea-souper? Or why your nose feels scratchy after a morning walk near the Yamuna? It's all about the air quality index (A Q I). A high A Q I, especially common around Diwali time and post-harvest season, means more pollutants are floating around – things like P M two point five (tiny particles) and ground-level ozone. These bad boys can really mess with your lungs and heart! Think back to the odd-even rule in Delhi back in two thousand and sixteen, remember? They were trying to cut down on vehicular emissions. It's a constant battle! We all contribute to the problem through burning fuels, driving vehicles, and sometimes even through stubble burning in states like Punjab and Haryana (a huge problem around October-November). What can we do? Simple things like using public transport (the Delhi Metro is a lifesaver!), planting trees (remember the Van Mahotsav campaigns?), and supporting policies that promote cleaner energy are all a good start. Also, being mindful of not burning things unnecessarily, especially during festival times like Holi and Diwali, can make a difference. The Central Pollution Control Board (C P C B) monitors air quality across the country, and you can usually find real-time data online. Knowledge is power! Let’s all pledge to breathe cleaner air. What are your thoughts and experiences with air quality in your city? Let's discuss! Remember, even small efforts combined can lead to big changes. Check the air quality on first January two thousand and twenty four at two P M – it’ll be eye-opening! And maybe plant a sapling before thirty first December two thousand and twenty four! Even a tiny tulsi plant helps. Think of it as your Diwali resolution for two thousand and twenty four!
